item.title: Slicehost rocks!
item.dc:creator: gary
item.description: There’s quite a bit of buzz about VPS hosting provider Slicehost these days. They’ve gotta be doing something right, there is currently a 52 day wait (!) for a new slice, and they are getting creative about how to increase cashflow and shorten the wait. We signed up with Slicehost a couple of months ago, [...]
item.content:encoded:
There’s quite a bit of buzz about VPS hosting provider Slicehost these days. They’ve gotta be doing something right, there is currently a 52 day wait (!) for a new slice, and they are getting creative about how to increase cashflow and shorten the wait.

We signed up with Slicehost a couple of months ago, and were lucky enough to have our slice created within minutes of filling out the registration form. That’s right, within 10 minutes we could log into our brand new ubuntu linux system with 1GB of RAM. So far we’ve been very happy with the price, performance and stability of our system. We are certainly getting more for our money than we were with our previous VPS host.

They seem to appeal most strongly to rails developers at this point, probably because they are knowledgeable rails hackers themselves. They keep adding helpful new features to the service such as rescue mode and the administration interface is simple and functional.

As you can tell we’re very pleased with Slicehost so far. I just hope they figure out a way to keep up with demand, because as good as they are not everyone can afford to wait 52 days to switch…

item.title: Faking Cursors with Chunkable
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: Jamis has a helpful post on faking cursors in ActiveRecord with some tricks to make it performant on large data sets. We’d run into the problem of making find(:all) calls for large queries would grind the machine down with so many objects loaded in memory. Thus far, we’ve taken the path Jamis explicitly avoids by using [...]
item.content:encoded:
Jamis has a helpful post on faking cursors in ActiveRecord with some tricks to make it performant on large data sets. We’d run into the problem of making find(:all) calls for large queries would grind the machine down with so many objects loaded in memory.

Thus far, we’ve taken the path Jamis explicitly avoids by using limit and offset. We extended ActiveRecord::Base to add an each_by_chunk method, like:

# Execute the given block (mandatory) on each item
# Selects the records in chunks of the given size.
def each_by_chunk(chunk_size = 500, options = {})
  offset = 0
  count = self.count

  options[:limit] = chunk_size

  while offset < count
    options[:offset] = offset
    self.find(:all, options).each do |obj|
      yield obj
    end

    offset += chunk_size
  end
end

Perhaps because many of our tables are not that large (<100,000 rows) we have not noticed performance problems for the large offsets. Also, it is rare that we need to do large batch operations. If we do see performance issues, we could replace our code with his solution. Yet another reason to subscribe to Jamis' blog, which is always chock full of tips and tricks. His blog (among others) demonstrates not only what you can do with Ruby and Rails, but how it should be done.

item.title: Searching with Solr
item.dc:creator: gary
item.description: John Munsch just posted about something I’ve been wanting to mention for a while now: replacing ferret with Solr for search. We had been cautiously satisfied users of ferret since the launch of tourb.us, but after a while a few things started to scare us. In particular, ferret’s very talented creator had embarked on rewriting the [...]
item.content:encoded:
John Munsch just posted about something I’ve been wanting to mention for a while now: replacing ferret with Solr for search.

We had been cautiously satisfied users of ferret since the launch of tourb.us, but after a while a few things started to scare us. In particular, ferret’s very talented creator had embarked on rewriting the core of the library in C for speed. This was welcome news when we heard about it, as the “mostly” ruby version that we were using had serious performance problems. But this rewrite was taking a long time to mature to the point where we would have been comfortable using it, and I was worried about how much the C version’s code would diverge from the stable Java code that the ruby version was based on.

These issues were discussed at the first RailsConf during Seth Fitzsimmon’s great Lucene Eye for the Ruby Guy talk. Seth mentioned Solr as perhaps the best choice for adding search to a large-scale rails deployment. We took a look when we got back from the conference and really liked what we saw. We wrote a Solr version of our own “acts_as_searchable”-like library, although if we were starting over today we’d probably use acts_as_solr.

Since we are both comfortable programming in Java, it was no problem building a version of our location-based searching for Solr. The whole thing is much faster than the ruby version of ferret that we were using and has been rock solid. It does chew up a fair amount of memory, and to be honest it has stretched our VPS hosting plan to its limits. But other than the occasional memory issue we have never needed to restart the Solr service.

In summary:

Solr Pros:

  • Uses the stable and highly-optimized Lucene code base, which is used on many high-traffic sites
  • Supports advanced features like configurable caching, replication, plugins and an admin interface
  • Both Solr and lucene are under active development
  • Easy to move the service to a beefier machine or a cluster if search becomes a bottleneck

Solr Cons:

  • Requires java for deployment and for plugin development (although jruby might come into play here)
  • Uses more memory than we’d like in our resource-constrained environments
  • Running a separate process adds some operational overhead

item.title: tourb.us in the Boston Globe
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: The Weekend section of today’s Boston Globe has an article on tourb.us, and fellow Boston-based concert tracker tourfilter. We’re happy with how it came out, and were pleasantly surprised to see it made the banner on the front page. Thanks to Matt Shaer for contacting us and pulling the piece together.
item.content:encoded: The Weekend section of today’s Boston Globe has an article on tourb.us, and fellow Boston-based concert tracker tourfilter. We’re happy with how it came out, and were pleasantly surprised to see it made the banner on the front page. Thanks to Matt Shaer for contacting us and pulling the piece together.

item.title: Pandora Road Trip @ MIT
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: Tonight I went to MIT to hear Tim Westergren, a founder from Pandora conduct a “town hall” about the past and future of their music service. Tim told the interesting story of having started Pandora just before the (first?) bubble burst, the intervening hardscrabble years and the somewhat-crazy Music Genome Project that catalogs each song [...]
item.content:encoded:
Tonight I went to MIT to hear Tim Westergren, a founder from Pandora conduct a “town hall” about the past and future of their music service. Tim told the interesting story of having started Pandora just before the (first?) bubble burst, the intervening hardscrabble years and the somewhat-crazy Music Genome Project that catalogs each song along 400 attributes. The most exciting feature (to me) of Pandora is their ability to make recommendations for music that is not popular (yet anyway) that sites like iTunes or Last.fm are less likely to recommend. The audience had lots of good questions (before I had to duck out) about data privacy, the user experience and Pandora’s business model.

Tim made some predictions about the future cost of music and how the landscape is changing. He stated that technology has already transformed the cost of recording and the means of distribution, and now it’s time for technology to help with promotion. Hear, hear!

item.title: Boston Globe on Audioblogging Growth
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: Today’s Boston Globe had a feature on the growing number of audioblogs covering Boston. I’ve been reading several of the profiled sites (clicky clicky, ExitFare , Hello Gina, bradley’s almanac) for a while, and the article pointed me at another couple. (In the dead trees edition the bloggers are featured in photos for the front [...]
item.content:encoded:
Today’s Boston Globe had a feature on the growing number of audioblogs covering Boston. I’ve been reading several of the profiled sites (clicky clicky, ExitFare , Hello Gina, bradley’s almanac) for a while, and the article pointed me at another couple. (In the dead trees edition the bloggers are featured in photos for the front of Living Arts. Usually using photos of bloggers is, um, not always appealing, but it was actually well done I thought.) The sites are a great way to see what people are excited about in the Boston scene, with my only complaint being that I don’t have enough time to check out all the songs, bands and shows that they recommend.

It seems like every week there is a story that confirms the fact that the music landscape is changing, whether it is Tower Records filing for bankruptcy or this story about how audioblogs are spreading the word from music fan to music fan.

item.title: Badges Redux: Bigger, Faster, Javascripty-er
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: We’ve just rolled out a new badge to easily share your upcoming shows on your website. Using the badge builder you can quickly pick a theme and copy-n-paste your way to a more dynamic blog. A little while back we put an image-based badge, and now are adding more customizable javascript + html + css [...]
item.content:encoded:
We’ve just rolled out a new badge to easily share your upcoming shows on your website. Using the badge builder you can quickly pick a theme and copy-n-paste your way to a more dynamic blog. A little while back we put an image-based badge, and now are adding more customizable javascript + html + css badges. And by sprinkling in a little time-based caching, the badge loads faster than you can clap your hands and say yeah.

Our blog is now decorated with our editorial picks of some Boston shows that we’re interested in. For some other examples in the wild with their own styles, check out: In Flight at Night, clicky clicky, and All That She Surveys. Get yours today.

item.title: Demod at Boston Web Innovators Meeting
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: Last night we were a “side dish” at the Boston Web Innovators event at the Royal Sonesta Hotel in Cambridge. It was a great opportunity to demo tourb.us to people as they mingled. We had a lot of interesting conversations — perhaps too many, as it was a bit of a blur and now I [...]
item.content:encoded:
Last night we were a “side dish” at the Boston Web Innovators event at the Royal Sonesta Hotel in Cambridge. It was a great opportunity to demo tourb.us to people as they mingled. We had a lot of interesting conversations — perhaps too many, as it was a bit of a blur and now I wish I’d taken better notes on back the business cards I received. The audience at the Webinno events tend to ask probing technical and business questions, and also offer helpful suggestions in both areas. The attendees are a mix of entrepreneurs, techies, and business folks, so there are a lot of different perspectives represented.

We got a lot of positive feedback on the site, which is always nice to hear in person since running a site is largely anonymous. And all the good questions are always a reminder of how much there is more to do (expand our coverage, make it easier to buy tickets, etc.), which is what we’re focused on. These meetings always have a very positive energy to them, and last night was no exception. Thanks to David Beisel for organizing another successful event.

item.title: Calling All Bands
item.dc:creator: mike
item.description: Are you in a promising, local band? Where you have some shady practice space and like playing local shows for fun and free drinks? Then we’d like to have a word with you. With tourb.us we’re aiming to give bands with shoestring budgets another way to promote their shows. We just rolled out a new feature [...]
item.content:encoded:
Are you in a promising, local band? Where you have some shady practice space and like playing local shows for fun and free drinks? Then we’d like to have a word with you.

With tourb.us we’re aiming to give bands with shoestring budgets another way to promote their shows. We just rolled out a new feature that let’s any band signup with tourb.us to add their shows and customize their profile. Adding your shows to tourb.us makes it simple for others to get reminders before shows, see who’s coming, or subscribe to your upcoming shows via RSS or iCal. Act now and we’ll throw in a little Google Maps mashup with your band’s shows that makes it easy to embed on your site with just a little copy and pasting. All for the low, low price of zero dollars.

And we’re always listening for feedback on how to make it a better service for bands.
